name: Structured Data Capture Value Set
publisher: U.S. Office of the National Coordinator (ONC)'s Standards and Infrastructure (S&I) Structured Data Capture project
description: Defines how ValueSet is used to reflect code lists found in data element defintions and form definitions to be used within the ONC's Structured Data Capture standard. : Structured Data Capture Value Set

element.name: StructuredDataCaptureValueSet
element.short: A set of codes drawn from one or more code systems
element.formal: A value set specifies a set of codes drawn from one or more code systems.

constraint.human: A value set with only one import SHALL also have an include and/or an exclude unless the value set defines its own codes
constraint.xpath: not(exists(f:compose)) or (count(f:compose/f:import)!=1 or exists(f:compose/f:include) or exists(f:compose/f:exclude) or exists(f:define))

constraint.human: A defined code system (if present) SHALL have a different identifier to the value set itself
Value set SHALL contain either a define, a compose, or an expansion element

element.formal: The logical id of the resource, as used in the url for the resoure. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comments: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation. Bundles always have an id, though it is usually a generated UUID.

element.formal: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.
unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.formal: The version specific identifier, as it appears in the version portion of the url. This values changes when the resource is created, updated, or deleted.
element.comments: The server assigns this value, and ignores what the client specifies, except in the case that the server is imposing version integrity on updates/deletes.

element.short: When the resource version last changed
element.formal: When the resource last changed - e.g. when the version changed.
element.comments: This value is always populated except when the resource is first being created. The server / resource manager sets this value; what a client provides is irrelevant.

element.short: Profiles this resource claims to conform to
element.formal: A list of profiles that this resource claims to conform to. The URL is a reference to Profile.url.
element.comments: It is up to the server and/or other infrastruture of policy to determine whether/how these claims are verified and/or updated over tiem.

element.short: Security Labels applied to this resource
element.formal: Security labels applied to this resource. These tags connect specific resources to the overall security policy and infrastructure.
element.comments: The security labels can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource.

element.formal: Tags applied to this resource. Tags are intended to to be used to identify and relate resources to process and workflow, and applications are not required to consider the tags when interpreting the meaning of a resource.
element.comments: The tags can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource.

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.formal: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.
element.comments: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element as much as possible.

element.formal: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comments:
Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource

Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.formal: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comments: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative.

element.formal: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comments: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

element.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.short: Globally unique logical id for  value set
element.formal: The identifier that is used to identify this value set when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or an instance (should be globally unique OID, UUID, or URI).

element.short: Logical id for this version of the value set
element.formal: The identifier that is used to identify this version of the value set when it is referenced in a specification, model, design or instance. This is an arbitrary value managed by the profile author manually and the value should be a timestamp.
element.comments: There may be multiple resource versions of the value set that have the same identifier.

element.short: Informal name for this value set
element.formal: A free text natural language name describing the value set.
element.comments: The name is not expected to be unique. A name should be provided unless the value set is a contained resource (e.g. an anonymous value set in a profile). Most registries will require a name.

element.short: Textual description of the intended scope and use
element.formal: This should describe "the semantic space" to be included in the value set. This can also describe the approach taken to build the value set.
element.comments: Any significantly meaningful change in this implies a different value set, rather than a new version.  This item is a key component for the meaning of the value set.

element.short: Indicates whether or not any change to the content logical definition may occur
element.formal: If this is set to 'true', then no new versions of the content logical definition can be created.  Note: Other metadata might still change.
element.comments:
Normally immutability is set to 'false', which is the default assumption if it is not populated.  Note that the implication is that if this is set to 'true', there may be only one Value Set Version for this Definition. Immutability tends to be set to 'true' in one of two cases:
- Where the value set, by the nature of its usage, cannot change.  For example "All specializations of ACT in ActClassCode"
- Where there's no safe way to express the "Purpose" such that someone else could safely make changes to the value set definition
Source workflow control must guarantee that the same URI always yields the same definition.

element.short: Name of the publisher (Organization or individual)
element.formal: The name of the individual or organization that published the value set.
element.comments: Usually an organization, but may be an individual. This item SHOULD be populated unless the information is available from context.
element.requirements: Helps establish the "authority/credibility" of the value set.  May also allow for contact.

element.formal: Contacts of the publisher to assist a user in finding and communicating with the publisher.
element.comments: May be a web site, an email address, a telephone number (tel:), etc.

element.short: Human language description of the value set
element.formal: A free text natural language description of the use of the value set - reason for definition, conditions of use, etc. The description may include a list of expected usages for the value set.
element.comments: The description is not intended to describe the semantics of the Value Set - there are no intrinsic semantics separate from the codes contained in its expansion. The description should capture its intended use, which is needed for ensuring integrity for its use in models across future changes. . A description should be provided unless the value set is a contained resource (e.g. an anonymous value set in a profile). Most registries will require a description.

element.short: Publishing restrictions for the value set
element.formal: A copyright statement relating to the value set and/or its contents. These are generally legal restrictions on the use and publishing of the value set.
element.comments: Frequently, the copyright differs between the value set, and codes that are included. The copyright statement should clearly differentiate between these when required.

element.formal: The status of the value set.
element.comments: Allows filtering of valuesets that are appropriate for use vs. not.
element.requirements: Identify when/if the value set should be used.

binding.name: ValueSetStatus
binding.description: The lifecycle status of a Value Set or Concept Map

element.short: If for testing purposes, not real usage
element.formal: This valueset was authored for testing purposes (or education/evaluation/marketing), and is not intended to be used for genuine usage.
element.comments: Allows filtering of valuesets that are appropriate for use vs. not.

element.short: Whether this is intended to be used with an extensible binding
element.formal: Whether this is intended to be used with an extensible binding or not.
element.requirements: It is not required to say whether this intent applies.

element.formal: The date that the value set status was last changed.
element.comments: Note that this is not the same as the resource last-modified-date, since the resource may be a secondary representation of the value set.
element.requirements: Need to know when a value set was first legal for use or became withdrawn or replaced.

element.short: Fixed date for the version of all referenced code systems and value sets
element.formal: If a Stability Date is expanded by evaluating the Content Logical Definition using the current version of all referenced code system(s) and value sets as of the Stability Date.
element.comments: With a defined Stability Date the value set is considered "Static".  Otherwise, the value set is considered to be "Dynamic" and may have different expansions as underlying code systems and/or value sets evolve.

element.short: When value set defines its own codes
element.formal: When value set defines its own codes.

constraint.human: Within a code system definition, all the codes SHALL be unique

element.formal: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.short: URI to identify the code system
element.formal: URI to identify the code system.

The version of this code system that defines the codes. Note that the version is optional because a well maintained code system does not suffer from versioning, and therefore the version does not need to be maintained. However many code systems are not well maintained, and the version needs to be defined and tracked.

element.short: If code comparison is case sensitive
element.formal: If code comparison is case sensitive when codes within this system are compared to each other.
element.comments: If this value is missing, then it is not specified whether a code system is case sensitive or not. When the rule is not known, Postel's law should be followed: produce codes with the correct case, and accept codes in any case. This element is primarily provided to support validation software.

element.name: concept
element.formal: Concepts in the code system.
unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.short: identifies the meaning of the extension
element.formal: Source of the definition for the extension code - a logical name or a URL.
element.comments: The definition may point directly to a computable or human-readable definition of the extensibility codes, or it may be a logical URI as declared in some other specification. The definition should be version specific.  This will ideally be the URI for the Resource Profile defining the extension, with the code for the extension after a #.

element.formal: Value of extension - may be a resource or one of a constrained set of the data types (see Extensibility in the spec for list).

element.name: conceptConceptOrder
element.formal: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: The presence of a sort order implies that sort order is important.

element.formal: The formal definition of the concept. Formal definitions are not required, because of the prevalence of legacy systems without them, but they are highly recommended, as without them there is no formal meaning associated with the concept.

element.name: designation
element.formal: Additional representations for the concept - other languages, aliases, specialised purposes, used for particular purposes, etc.
element.requirements: many concept definition systems support mltiple representations, in multiple languages, and for mltiple purposes.

element.formal: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.formal: The language this designation is defined for.
element.comments: In the absense of a language, the resource language applies.

element.short: Details how this designation would be used
element.formal: A code that details how this designation would be used.
element.comments: if no use is provided, the designation can be assumed to be suitable for general display to a human user.

binding.name: ConceptDesignationUse
binding.description: Details of how a designation would be used

element.short: The text value for this designation
element.formal: The text value for this designation.

element.short: Import the contents of another value set
element.formal: Includes the contents of the referenced value set as a part of the contents of this value set.
element.comments: The value set URI is either a logical reference to a defined value set such as a SNOMED CT reference set, or a literal reference to a value set definition (not an expansion). If the reference is a logical one, it may not reference a actual FHIR value set resource; in this case, the referenced definition of a set of coded values needs to be clear about how versions are resolved.

element.name: include
element.short: Include one or more codes from a code system
element.formal: Include one or more codes from a code system.
element.comments: If there are no codes or filters, the entire code system is included. Note that the set of codes hat are included may contain abstract codes.

element.formal: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.short: The system the codes come from
element.formal: The code system from which the selected codes come from.
element.comments: See *Coding.system* for further documentation.

element.short: Specific version of the code system referred to
element.formal: The version of the code system that the codes are selected from.
element.comments: This is used when selecting the descendents of a concept - they may change between versions. If no version is specified, then the exact contents of the value set may not be known until a context of use binds it to a particular version.

element.short: A concept defined in the system
element.formal: Specifies a concept to be included or excluded.
element.comments: The list of concepts is considered ordered, though the order may not have any particular significance. Typically, the order an an expansion follows that defined in the compose.

element.formal: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.formal: Specifies a code for the concept to be included or excluded.
element.comments: Expressions are allowed if defined by the underlying code system.

element.short: Test to display for this code for this value set
element.formal: The text to display to the user for this concept in the context of this valueset. If no display is provided, then applications using the value set use the display specified for the code by the system.
element.comments: The value set resource allows for an alternative display to be specified for when this concept is used in this particular value set. See notes in the value set narrative about the correct use of this element.

element.formal: Additional representations for this concept when used in this value set - other languages, aliases, specialised purposes, used for particular purposes, etc.

element.short: Select codes/concepts by their properties (including relationships)
element.formal: Select concepts by specify a matching criteria based on the properties (including relationships) defined by the system. If multiple filters are specified, they SHALL all be true.
element.comments: Selecting codes by specifying filters based on properties is only possible where the underlying code system defines appropriate properties. Note that in some cases, the underlying code system defines the logical concepts but not the literal codes for the concepts. In such cases, the literal definitions may be provided by a third party.

element.formal: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.short: A property defined by the code system
element.formal: A code that identifies a property defined in the code system.

element.short: = | is-a | is-not-a | regex | in | not in
element.formal: The kind of operation to perform as a part of the filter criteria.

binding.name: FilterOperator
binding.description: The kind of operation to perform as a part of a property based filter

element.short: Code from the system, or regex criteria
element.formal: The match value may be either a code defined by the system, or a string value which is used a regex match on the literal string of the property value.
element.comments: Use regex matching with care - full regex matching on every SNOMED CT term is prohibitive, for example.

element.formal: Exclude one or more codes from the value set.
element.comments: Usually this is used to selectively exclude codes that were included by subsumption in the inclusions. Any display names specified for the codes are ignored.

element.short: Used when the value set is "expanded"
element.formal: A value set can also be "expanded", where the value set is turned into a simple collection of enumerated codes. This element holds the expansion, if it has been performed.
element.comments: Expansion is performed to produce a collection of codes that are ready to use for data entry or validation.

element.comments: This SHOULD have be a fully populated instant, but in some circumstances, value sets are expanded by hand, of the expansion is published without that precision.

element.formal: The system in which the code for this item in the expansion is defined.

element.short: If user cannot select this entry
element.formal: If true, this entry is included in the expansion for navigational purposes, and the user cannot select the code directly as a proper value.
element.comments: This shouldn't be understood to exclude its use for searchig (e..g by subsumption testing). The client should know whether it is appropriate for the user to select an abstract code or not.

element.short: Version in which this code / display is defined
element.formal: The version of this code system that defined this code and/or display. This should only be used with code systems that do not enforce concept permanence.
element.comments: The exact value of the version string is specified by the system from which the code is derived.

element.short: Code - if blank, this is not a choosable code
